#Text=Page using Template : Infobox artist with unknown parameter " bgcolour " ( this message is shown only in preview ) .

#Text=( 1548/50 [ 1 ] – 14 October 1628 ) , best known as Jacopo or Giacomo Palma il Giovane or simply Palma Giovane ( " Young Palma " ) , [ 2 ] was an Italian painter from Venice and a notable exponent of the Venetian school .
#Text=After Tintoretto ' s death ( 1594 ) , Palma became Venice 's dominant artist perpetuating his style . [ 3 ]

#Text=Outside Venice , he received numerous commissions in the area of Bergamo , then part of the Venetian Domini di Terraferma , and in Central Europe , most prominently from the connoisseur emperor Rudolph II in Prague .

#Text=Born into a family of painters , he was the great-nephew of the painter Palma Vecchio ( " Old Palma " ) and the son of Antonio Nigreti ( 1510/15-1575/85 ) , a minor painter who was himself the pupil of the elder Palma 's workshop foreman Bonifacio de ' Pitati [ 4 ] and who after Bonifazio 's death ( 1553 ) inherited Bonifacio 's shop and clientele ; the younger Palma seems to have polished his style making copies after Titian .
#Text=In 1567 Guidobaldo II della Rovere , duke of Urbino , recognized Palma 's talents , supporting him for four years and sending him to Rome , where he remained until about 1572 .
#Text=Shedding most remnants of Roman manner after his return to Venice , Palma adopted the inescapable models and mannerisms of Tintoretto .
#Text=His early biographers assert that he found a place in the ageing Titian ' s workshop ; when the master died , Palma stepped in to finish his last work , the Pietà in the Accademia , Venice .
#Text=Palma 's first major public commission arrived after a 1577 fire in the Doge 's Palace : three scenes in its grand council hall .
#Text=By the mid-1580s he had digested Tintoretto ' s versatile figure postures and Titian ' s thick surfaces , emphasis on light , and loose brushstroke .
#Text=In Palma Giovane 's output , Freedberg detects also " an occasional discursive opulence à la Veronese ; and inclinations towards descriptive naturalism à la Bassano .

#Text=Rejecting Mannerism in the 1580s , he embraced a reformist naturalism [ 6 ] he varied the ingeniously synthesised amalgam according to subject matter and patrons ' own eclectic and conservative tastes , with  virtuoso skill and a facile intelligence .

#Text=Among these there is the magnificent portrait of Saint Pope Pius V , commissioned by the Bellanti Counts , an influential family who gave four  Capitani del Popolo " to the city of Siena in the Middle Ages .

column1: #Text=After three centuries in Tuscany , it was bought by Sir Robert Dick in 1842 .

#Text=After another two hundred years , the portrait was bought from Bonham 's in London , one of the most ancient auction houses in the world , founded in 1793 and thanks to Roberto Gagliardi it was brought back to Tuscany where it can be admired at the Chianciano Museum of Art , a few kilometres from Siena . [ 8 ]

#Text=Palma il Giovane went on to organize his own , large studio which he used to produce a repetitive series of religious and allegorical pictures that can be found throughout the territory of the Venetian Republic .
#Text=After 1600 he painted mythologies for a small circle of intellectuals .
#Text=After the death of Tintoretto in 1594 , he remained one of the leading painters in the City of Venice .
#Text=He was interred in the Basilica di San Giovanni e Paolo , a traditional burial place of the doges .
#Text=Among his followers was the Brescian painter , Camillo Rama .
